column1: In the latter part of April fifty-three courses of granite masonry
column2: rising to the height of seventy feet above high water
column4: and thirty-six courses remained to be set. The old lighthouse had been already overtopped. As the work advances toward completion the question arises: What shall be done with John Smeaton's famous tower
column5: which has done such admirable service for 120 years? One proposition is to take it down to the level of the top of the solid portion
column6: and leave the rest as a perpetual memorial of the great work which Smeaton accomplished in the face of obstacles vastly greater than those which confront the modern architect. The London News says: "Were Smeaton's beautiful tower to be literally consigned to the waves
column7: we should regard the act as a national calamity
column9: if public funds are not available for its conservation
column10: we trust that private zeal and munificence may be relied on to save from destruction so interesting a relic. It certainly could not cost much to convey the building in sections to the mainland
column13: to re-erect it as a national tribute to the genius of its great architect."
